text:
This is a regular in our house. I make a reduced calorie version:  -thin sliced chicken breast -reduced fat thin sliced provolone  -1 slice of thin sliced deli ham  For bread crumbs, I first dip chicken in egg, then use a mixture of plain bread crumbs seasoned with our favorite Susie Q's Santa Maria Style seasoning.  We dip it in honeymustard dressing & serve with a side of whole grain brown rice & my homemade applesauce!

I took the advice of others and dipped the rolled chicken in butter before rolling in breadcrumbs.  I cooked them at 400 degrees for 45 min., which was perfect.  I also made a sauce from cream of chicken soup with various herbs because, based on other reviewers comments, I thought the chicken may be a little dry.  However, the chicken was moist and tender and the sauce was not needed.  Very good recipe that makes a beautiful presentation on the plate.

text:
This was disappointing to me, because of the high ratings.  Upon reading dozens and dozens of them, I found most were not rating the original recipe but the changes they made TO this one.  I did like not having to roll the chicken in breadcrumbs.  That was a time saver.  I also made a sauce out of cream of chicken soup, sour cream, and zesty honey mustard.  I pounded my chicken thin, but it was nowhere near done after the 35 minutes stated.  I had to turn the oven up to 400 and let it go another 20 minutes.  Bottom line is that this was good, but nothing special.

text:
I just have to say, please do NOT add ANY salt to this dish. I failed to remember that the ham already has enough salt flavor. My family loved this even if it was a tad bit salty. I dipped the filled and rolled chicken in egg wash and then rolled in bread crumbs. I did not melt cheese on top but instead made a cream sauce with heavy cream, butter, paprika, dry white wine and a bit of corn starch. This was so good and easy, I'll do it again and again. I would recommend a little black pepper on the chicken before rolling. Just no salt!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the previous reviews,I made some changes to this dish. I took a short cut and used the thin cut chicken breasts. I added a swipe of dijon mustard on the inside of the chicken breast and after rolling and securing with toothpicks, dipped the chicken in an eggwash before rolling in a mixture of breadcrumbs.  Finally I made a sauce to go with the chicken: a can of cream of chicken and herbs soup, a cup of white wine, a tablespoon of lemon juice, a half cup of sour cream and salt, pepper and garlic powder to taste.  It was delicious but I did find that it took much longer than the total of 35 minutes to cook.  I had to raise the temp to 425 and cooked it for another 12 minutes to finish it off.  I did cover the chicken at that time with foil to prevent it from getting too brown.  Overall, a good dish.

text:
I've made this twice, once as directed and once using eggwash and more breadcrumbs as suggested by other reviewers.  Both times it was very tasty.  The first time is considerably lighter, and the breadcrumbs act just as a bit of texture difference.  Using the eggwash, they took on a breading function.  Both very good, and very different.  Next time I'm going to try a little dijon mustard on the inside, which I think would round out the flavors.

This turned out great! I've never had Chicken Cordon Bleu before, not even in a restaraunt. I followed some of your tips though. I purchased thin-cut chicken breasts (Foster Farms) and pounded them out a little more. I dipped them in egg and then Italian bread crumbs. I used Black Forest Ham and swiss cheese. city:

country:

text:
I made this last night, it was the first time I ever made this and it turned out great!!! Not a bite left. Everyone loved it. It was so easy and so good!! I of course checked out the reviews before trying, and got some good suggestions. After pounding chicken, I dipped chicken in egg wash, put bread crumbs on a plate and laid chicken on top, then put cheese and ham on top, and simply rolled it up. No hassle and not much mess. I forgot to get toothpicks, so just put on baking sheet seam side down, and they didn't unroll. I put swiss cheese on top last 5 mins of baking, and while cooling, made a cream sauce with cream of chicken soup about 1 cup of sour cream, I didn't have any lemon juice, so I seasoned with a bit of lemon pepper seasoning. We served with brown rice, and steamed broccoli...Yum!!! Great success!!!

text:
So good! My whole family loved it. It was quick and extremely easy. I had HUGE chicken breasts, so I just sliced them half (like cutlets). No pounding, easy rolling. After rolling, I dipped them in beaten egg before coating in breadcrumbs. Then I put a small pat of butter on top of each roll. Like another reviewer, I also made the honey/mustard sauce from the Aussie Chicken recipe from this site. (Note: If you make that sauce, leave out the corn syrup. It's NOT necessary!). It was so good, I'm making it for the second time in a week!

text:
I love chicken cordon bleu, but I've always been afraid that I wouldn't have much success making it myself. This recipe makes it so simple though! I like to season my chicken with salt, pepper, and garlic powder and to use seasoned breadcrumbs. I dip the rolled chicken in a beaten egg before dredging in the breadcrumbs. I've also found that thinly sliced smoked deli ham works the best in this recipe. I'll definitely be making this again, and I can't wait to try it with the recommended honey mustard sauce.

Display Name:
JUSTCYN

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/228953.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Its not the recipes fault but pounding meat, for me, is always disappointing. I use the flat side of an official meat mallet but I always end up with mushy spots and tears making it difficult to roll up. Maybe I am pounding it too hard and it requires a more delicate touch. Whenever I go easy on it though it seems like its not flattening the meat at all! I used sort of small breast filets thinking I would just fill them with less ham and cheese. But I will use large ones in the future like the recipe recommends. I also breaded both sides of the chicken before rolling it up because hubby likes breaded stuff and it sounded like a good idea from another reviewer. It added a nice flavor dimension but doing that, instead of breading the rolled up package, makes the rolling really messy. I should have breaded the inside only becasue I needed to re-bread the outside of the roll afterwards anyway. I used pieces of rather thick spiral sliced leftover ham and my Swiss cheese wasnt too thin either. This made rolling even harder. I used the honey mustard sauce from the Aussie Chicken recipe. Hubby likes honey mustard stuff so I knew that would go over well. Presentation wasnt too lovely but hubby gave the Chicken Cordon Bleu thumbs up so it gets five stars.

text:
I made this last week for company and they loved it! I brought left overs the next day to my parents and I got a 2 minute voice mail message from them raving about how it was better than anything they have had in a restaurant and they waned to know how I had made it! It was so much easier than I expected. I got a tip from a cook that I could pound the chicken thin enough by using a can as a tool to spread the chicken out. I put a ziploc bag over it and the can was heavy enough that this worked pretty well! I didn't have any problems wrapping it. I also used the tips here about adding the paprika, breading the entire chicken and I made the sauce suggested to go with the Aussie chicken which REALLY made the dish! I highly recommend!

I just changed a couple of little things.  Instead of pounding the chicken, I just kind of butterflied the breasts, and folded them over the cheese and ham...and then toothpicked them at the seams.  I also brushed the breasts with butter before coating them with breadcrumbs.  They turned out just the teensiest bit dry, so I think next time I'll cover the pan with foil while baking.  I'm told they were excellent, though (I'm a vegetarian).  :-)

None
text:
Great recipe!!!  I use different cheeses for different taste.  We use swiss, havarti, provolone, cheddar etc.  If you need to pound the chicken and don't have a mallet, just place chicken in a zip lock bag, take a frying pan and hit the bag.  Works just as good as a mallet.  You can even use a rolling pin.  I don't recommend using string.  If you get the chicken thin enough the tooth picks should work.  Thank you for such an awesome recipe.

This was really good.  My husband has now declared this his favorite meal.  I used muenster cheese because we do not care for swiss. text:
Recipe was WONDERFUL.  I purchased a 3 lb bag of boneless/skinless breasts and used the whole bag.  Some rolls were larger than others but they all turned out moist cooking the same amount of time.  (Used 9 x 13 pan) I did add 10 min to the cooking time.  I also took the suggestion of others and spread mayo on the rolls prior to adding the bread crumbs.  I made a sauce of 1 can cream of celery soup and 3/4 cup sour cream. YUMMY!!  My husband and I fought over who got the leftovers today for lunch.  Will make again for sure.

text:
I pounded each breast thin with the bottom of my heaviest glass since my broken tenderizer/pounder has not been replaced yet. I then placed two slices of cheese next to the chicken since the breasts were rather large, then two slices of extremely thin ham, rolled up, sprinkled with Italian bread crumbs, salt  pepper and garlic powder. Did not add more cheese at the end. I served Garlic Green Beans with this. What is really nice about this dish is that it is fast for a weeknight family dinner but is company worthy at the same time.

I give this a five star for its simplicity and at the same time it was very tasty. Instead of making honey mustard I made up some Bernaise Sauce using a package that you add milk and butter. This is a favorite at our house.  I use medium size breasts and pound them out, and sort of tuck in the sides as I roll.  Both of my kids love these, and it is probably one of my husbands favorite dishes.  It does need a sauce, and a very simple one is just to mix some mayo and mustard together. https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674157.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious.  Modified it like so:  After rolling up and securing with toothpicks, rolled in 2 beaten eggs, then in cracker crumbs.  After putting in baking pan, sprayed nonstick spray over each breast.  Baked for 45 minutes.  Served with a honey mustard sauce:  Mixed 3/4 c mayo, 1/4 c mustard, 3/16 c honey, a couple dashes of worcestire sauce, and 1/3 grated onion.    YUMMY!!!

text:
This recipe was wonderful!  I followed the advice of previous reviews and mixed dijon mustard and one tbsp of mayonnaise to smear on the inside of the chicken breasts before I added the ham and cheese.  I also followed the idea for the sauce.  I was out of sour cream so I used 1 can cream of celery soup and a big spoon of dijon mustard.  After wrapping the chicken I rolled it in the sauce and then the breadcrumbs.  It turned out tender and really tasty.  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
Delicious!!  I had two really large chicken breasts, so I just split them down the middle and pounded them flat.  Then rolled them up and dipped them in egg and then bread crumbs.  It was very easy and very good - we also made the sauce that someone recommended in the comments (1 can cream of chicken soup, 1/2 cup sour cream, 1 tbsp lemon juice) and it was fantastic.  Great recipe - thanks!!!

text:
I love this recipe, simple is best!  I flattened chicken thighs, added salt and pepper, Boars Head ham and Swiss, and rolled them in seasoned brown rice flour.  I sprayed the chicken with grape seed oil and air fried them.  I love it because it saves some fat, is a bit healthier, all while retaining that juicy inside and crispy crust.  I made garlic mashed potatoes and it was absolutely delicious!

userID:
3059233
Display Name:
slcgirl3
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

madeRecipesCount:
51
favoritesCount:

recipesCount:

reviewsCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674137.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've made this one many times now, and it's delicious every time!  This last time I used frozen chicken breast.  I defrosted it in the microwave, then filleted it (since I wasn't sure how frozen it was inside). So then I had two pieces of chicken. 
 Then used a meat tenderizer to flatten each one a bit.  Seasoned each with salt and pepper, then added two layers of deli Swiss and honey ham (a slice of ham, then Swiss, then ham, then Swiss) to each.  Rolled them up and gently covered each with an egg wash (which also had salt and pepper).  Rolled each one in a pan of bread crumbs, then secured them with a couple toothpicks each.  I sprinkled a little more bread crumbs on top.  Then I put a couple pats of butter on each one.  Cooked uncovered at 350 for about 40 minutes.  Took it out and put a slice of Swiss cheese on the top of each one, then put it  back in the oven for another 5 mins.  It was cooked all the way through, really moist, and delicious!  I loved the extra slice of ham and Swiss inside.  I think I will have to remember to do that next time, too!  I tried something else new - I tried making the sauce of 1 can of cream of chicken soup and  1/2 cup of sour cream.  It was good, but I felt it was a little bland.  It needs some seasoning (but I'm not entirely sure what!).  My family seemed to enjoy the sauce, and everyone definitely enjoyed the chicken.  And I had just enough for a very yummy lunch today! ;)

text:
This was a success at my house! I cooked it a little hotter and a little shorter (25 minutes at about 400) and it seemed to stay juicier than a few were mentioning. I did use too hard of a Swiss cheese, so next time I plan to use a softer Swiss and more ham. Also, the chicken was a little bland with just salt and pepper, so I plan to add a little of our own favorite seasoning on the next go around. Overall, easy to make and turned out well. Warms up great for good work lunch leftovers also.

I made it mostly as the recipe except I made 6 breasts for our family. The chicken was moist & we absolutely loved it. I used graham cracker crumbs instead of bread crumbs for just a tinge of sweetness. I use them in all my recipes that call for bread crumbs. I also rolled them in the crumbs after I rolled the breast & before I put the toothpicks in. Next time I may put in another slice of ham or cheese, or both. Overall very easy, yummy, & tasty!

text:
I use a little garlic and onion powder with the seasoning and I have also used a little italian blend seasoning.  I floured prepared breast lightly, dip in egg and buttermilk and roll again in flour OR crumbs (double dip) I then fry them, just like frying chicken.  You may have a little chesse run out the sides but it's ok.  These will melt in your mouth.  Give me fried chicken any way except with a waffle.  I also use toothpicks to help hold together especially when I make smaller ones. (lot more work but the grandkids love them.)

text:
Love this. Couldn't be simpler. I split the chicken breasts lengthwise so they are thinner, sometimes don't have to pound them and sometimes do so minimally. We love the flavor, the ease of preparing, and the fact that the chicken stays so moist.
I can't recall if I got the idea from other reviewers or other recipes, but often will brush a thin layer of dijon mustard inside the  chicken breast for more flavor too. 
I made a bunch and transported them to my mom's, cooked them once there while visiting with all.

text:
Outstanding Dish!  Very simple to make.  the only prep was beating down the chicken breast.  Really enjoyed making this.  I made a few adjustments.  Used 2 slices of cooked Ham, 1 slice of Swiss Cheese, rolled the rolled up prepared breast in Egg Beaters and then in the Bread Crumbs.  Also put a 1/2 slice of Swiss Cheese on top for 5 minutes, after cooking @ 350 for 35 minutes.

Also made Sauce.  1 can Cream of Chicken Soup, 1/2 cup of Sour Cream and 1 TLB of Lemon Juice. Mixed and Heated for the last 5 minutes.  Used as a dipping sauce.

Thank You for an excellent recipe!

text:
super easy and fun to make.  I sliced open the breast into a larger fillet and flattened it easily inside a ziplock bag, hitting it with a rolling pin.  It doesn't take much force.  Then placed three Land o Lake deli ham slices and sliced up a a few pieces of cheese from a block of swiss cheese and rolled it up, securing with some tooth picks.  I used Panko gluten free breading and sprinkled Weber garlic and her seasoning, onion powder, garlic powder and garlic salt  and it smells amazing... It's not even cooked yet!  I've always wanted to make this and I finally have.  I will post picture if I can figure this out.  lol

This was really tasty and easy to make!  I added Parmesan cheese in the bread crumb mixture along with some garlic powder and pepper.  I made four as its just my husband and I so then we had the other two the following day just to save some time. I used regular sized breasts and pounded the heck out of them and rolled them up with cheese from the pre-sliced cheese packages and Black Forest ham that I use for my hubbies lunch (sorry honey)!  I rolled them up from the fat end first and ended up only using one toothpick. Dont forget to tell people they are there,  oopsie!  Place them in the appropriate sized pan and for easier clean up I first lined it with parchment paper. Brush the tops with whatever you fancy to make the crumbs stick. I used a beaten egg but Im sure oil or milk will do. Cover the chicken with the crumbs and pop into the oven. I didnt have a problem with 400 degrees for 25 minutes especially seeing as you put the cheese on at the end for another five minutes. Really enjoyed this recipe and was not as fiddley as I thought it would be. Will definitely make this again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5578346.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a hit but I had to make some changes. Saw a lot of comments about it being dry and that's probably because it bakes for too long. After sprinkling the breadcrumbs on it and rolling it around the coat, I sear it in a pan with butter on all four sides, no time table needed, just sear until it's golden brown, preferably on an oven safe pan because I then pop it in a 350 degree oven for 10-15 minutes. If you want a sauce to go with it, I personally recommend a white wine sauce which is more or less just a white wine reduction with veloute sauce. I served it with gratin dauphinoise but it would go nice with veggies if you decide to do the sauce.

text:
I made a few changes but came out great. I followed some other reviews and did and egg wash and used a plate for the bread crumbs so it would be on the whole piece of chicken. I also added paprika to the bread crumbs and S&P. My husband cant stop raving about it. It came out SO GOOD. I also made a sauce. Can of cream of chicken, 1/2 cup sour cream, a little lemon, salt pepper and paprika. Threw it in a sauce pan and warned it up, super simple. I made green beans as well and my husband LOVED them. Mixed hericot verts (green beans) with salt, pepper, olive oil, paprika and probably about a 1/2 TBS of Dijon mustard. Threw them on a jelly roll pan and cooked them in the oven with the chicken. I did about 400 degrees for 20

I used pork instead of chicken on accident... whoops...
I did not bread the meat so it would go along with my boyfriend's keto diet. I used a pork chop (this is what happens when you have a vegetarian cook you meat) and cut it in half lengthways and folded it out into a flat oval instead of pounding it. Baked for 25 minutes at 350, then put a slice of cheese on top and put it in for another 2 minutes. It turned out great!

text:
I make this a bit different. I do the egg wash, then spread a TBS of Honey Mustard mixed with Mayo on top of the ham slice before I add the Swiss cheese. I roll it up then pat on Panko breadcrumbs all over it that I have added some garlic powder, onion powder and Parmesan cheese to. I drizzle melted butter on them before baking. They are really awesome this way. Crispy, buttery, garlicky goodness. YUM!

I actually made this with turkey breast, and therefore I was a bit worried about the comments of the chicken being dry. To avoid this I used a bit of butter as my first layer, then added the ham and cheese. So it was kind of turkey cordon blue Kiev. :)

The result was really outstanding, I can highly recommend it!

text:
This was delicious, just kind of a pain to make (for my future reference!).  I had huge breasts to work with and had a hard time getting them flat. It was also difficult getting them to roll up - but I did. Sorta.  I used an egg wash, Panko crumbs and a pat of butter on top of each breast. Then I covered them loosely with aluminum foil to lock in the juices. I baked them for an hour and fifteen minutes.  They came out beautifully and everyone raved at the presentation and the flavor.  However, I'll probably only make this a couple of times a year. Served with baked potatoes and broccoli with cheese sauce.

text:
This is so easy and fast. No browning, sauce making or other time-consuming steps. I cut the rolled breasts in half before inserting the wooden sticks (I had long ones which my hubby cut in half for me...much sturdier than the lowly tooth pick). I then left the sticks in place when I served them and the guests had no trouble eating around them and the rolls didn't fall apart. Six breasts fed eight people with three halves left over. Will be making this often.

I always make any recipe I try as written the first time, before making any changes. This was very good as written so will make it again. I think I will try some of the suggestions of other reviewers like the egg rinse before the bread crumbs and a pat of butter on top of the chicken breast before baking. I don't understand how some people found this dry...mine were very moist so don't feel I need any extra sauce like some do. I served this with Pasta Pomodoro from this site and they went very well together.

text:
This turned out very good, flavor-wise.  The chicken breasts that I purchased were very thick, so pounding them to 1/4" thick would have taken more time and effort than I had available, so they ended up between 1/3 and 1/2 inch thick instead.  After rolling with the ham and cheese and securing with a toothpick, I rolled them in an egg wash followed by seasoned bread crumbs, rather than just sprinkling the bread crumbs on top.  This seemed to help immensely in providing a fully coated end result.The presentation would have been better if the chicken had been pounded to 1/4" thickness, but it di

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674138.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is soooo easy and so good! I kinda did a frugal college student version of this because I don't have the one that the recipe says but it still worked fine. Although it wouldn't taste the same as the original, it's still good. I used American instead of swiss cheese because I already have one that I use for sandwich. Just don't use the Kraft singles, it doesn't melt well. Then I used ham sandwich, also worked out just fine. For chicken, I don't have the hammer thing or a rolling pin so I just laid the chicken down the counter with foil underneath and used my knuckles and a mug to press it down. I dipped the chicken in egg wash before putting bread crumbs. I wrapped the chicken individually just to keep the melted cheese in there and it's easier to bring to school. Then baked it at 400 for 30 mins.

This turned out wonderfully.
I put my chicken on a raised wired rack set in a lined cookie sheet and used crushed plain corn flakes in place of the bread crumbs (didn't have the bread crumbs on hand). The wired rack allowed the chicken to get "crispy" texture without over cooking.

text:
I made this exactly as written. It didn't  brown  muchat all. A bit dry and quite bland.  The time suggestions are low. Of the 20 or so times I have made some version or another of chicken cordon bleu it has never taken me ten minutes to assemble, and this was no exception. It takes me at least five minutes per breast to flatten to an adequate thinness to roll and still it is never thin enough to fit more ham and cheese, which is what I think makes a better cordon bleu. So, really prep time was more like 30-45 minutes.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loved it! Although I made some changes. I did not tendrize the chicken. Instead, I made shallow criss-cross cuts on the chicken fillet. I added some turmeric and chicken powder in the rub. For the filling, I spread a layer of basil pesto and a slice of swiss cheese, dipped in scrambled eggs, and the rolled in bread crumbs. I also individually wrapped them with foil. After 35 mins of baking, I removed the foil and bake for additional 30-35 mins or until golden brown. The chicken was so moist! It was both tasty and fragrant. I will surely make some more next time.

Display Name:
judy2304

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/871418.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I gave this recipe 5 stars because I used basically the same ingredients, but put them together a little differently. Instead of pounding the chicken breasts to flatten them, I cut a pocket in the side of each the length of the breast.  I cut the Swiss slices in half and put them into the pocket so they would cover the length of the pocket. Then I put pieces of ham into the pocket. I folded the top of the pocket over the bottom, dipped each in an egg mix, and then in the bread crumbs. Then I baked them in a Reynolds wrap lined baking pan with the folded pocket down in the NuWave oven.  These came out great, and the leftovers froze beautifully for another meal.

text:
Unlike everyone else, I made it exactly as the recipe called for. My only suggestion from my experience, is to reduce the amount of cook time. I think it was probably a little overdone, which probably  resulted in some of the cheese leaking out of the meat rollup.  It is definitely a recipe that a man would like. The sauce is hearty and tasty  and this is an easy basic recipe. It goes well with a  whole-grain or spinach  pasta if you use the sauce on it.

Display Name:
WV Home Chef
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was able to buy chicken breast already pounded down thin from our local butcher so I used them. I sprayed my dish with pam and put salt and pepper on both sides of the chicken. I rolled up the chicken with a full slice of honey ham and a full slice of swiss cheese. I held it together with a toothpick. I mixed a can of cream of chicken soup, 1/2 can of milk and a 1/2 cup (give or take) I usually don't measure, just put in what I think of sour cream. Poured that on the top of the chicken. I put plain panko bread crumbs on top and baked covered in oven for 45 minutes. I then uncovered and baked for another 5 minutes. It turned out great. Mouth watering, nothing left good.  Thank you so much for sharing your recipe.

None
text:
This looked like a very easy recipe to follow and after reading some of the reviews, I went ahead and tried it. Because I am basically a lazy cook, instead of pounding the breasts I butterflied them and placed the ham and cheese inside. I took a few people's advice and used an egg wash and added a small pat of butter on top. I used GF seasoned panko breadcrumbs. They turned out delicious, not dry at all. Served them on a bed of wild and brown rice and didn't use any sauce or gravy. I would definitely make this again.

userID:
20296905
Display Name:
danielle092
isPro:

followersCount:
1

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/4459457.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I first didn't cut my chicken breasts in half. I cut a small hole in the center of the side and sliced the inter part of the breast to only  fillet it so the cheese would hold in better. (Imagine a ballon, the area you put your mouth on is smaller then the ballon itself.) I then rolled the ham like a taco, around the cheese and stuffed it into the small hole of the breast. I dipped the chicken in an egg wash before breading it. In the breading, I added garlic spices, salt, pepper, paprika and Kraft  parmesan cheese. I used tooth picks after to help hold the filling in place. I then placed the chicken with the opening of the stuffing sitting  upright. I cook chicken enough know when it done, it all depends on the thickness.  Once it's been made a few times, it becomes easier and easier.

text:
I cut large breasts in half lengthwise so they were already pretty thin before I pounded them out.  I rolled them up and dipped the rolls in egg and then covered the entire chicken roll in the bread crumbs instead of just sprinkling the tops.  
I also took other reviewers advice and made a sauce out of a can of cream of chicken soup, about half a cup of sour cream and about a tablespoon of lemon juice and adjusted to my taste.   This was much simpler than I anticipated and tasted great!

This recipe is amazing. Simple to make doesn't take a lot of prep time. I did make 2 slight changes because of my family's preferences. I used mozzarella cheese as we are not too keen on Swiss and I used crushed corn flakes for the breading, gives it a slightly sweet taste and is great for anyone who's gluten sensitive. Thank you to whoever posted this recipe my daughter gets so excited when she knows we are having this for dinner.

text:
I found this recipe when searching for new dish inspirations for my boyfriend's lunchbox, hence didn't have a taste on the first try. Later in the day I received my boyfriend's text message at work and told me how much he LOVE it and urge me to made again during weekend. I did and yum...it is absolutely delicious!

I made some changes base on personal preference - I use the boneless chicken thigh instead of breast, and marinade the chicken with salt, pepper, paprika and garlic powder for 10 mins before wrapping. I dip the meat  with egg wash then coat with bread crumb. Definitely will be one of the signature dishes in the household!

This turned out great! Have made a few times now. I did edit a few things though: I doubled up on cheese inside the chicken inside of putting a slice on top. Also for the breading, I breaded them like my family always does: flour, egg, then the breadcrumbs (thicker, tastier breading). Also don't forget to take the toothpicks out as I did after my first attempt ;)

text:
This is my second time making this recipe.  I made the breading out of crushed cornflakes mixed with enough melted butter to make clump and stick to the chicken.  I used a light sprinkle of lowry's seasoned salt in place of the salt and pepper and also a bit in the cornflake mix.  The first time, I used a thin sliced black forest ham.  The second time, I used a thicker sliced ham off the bone with the hard edges trimmed off.  The second one was much better.  My family loved it!

text:
I gave this 4 stars instead of 5  because I changed the recipe a little.  I followed the advice of others and dipped the rolled chicken in an egg wash and then coated it in breadcrumbs.  The addition of the egg wash just made the breadcrumbs stick better and be a little crunchier.  I otherwise followed the recipe as written.  Prosciutto is the traditional ham used for this so I used that and it was really good!

text:
Came out great. Very important to get large Chicken breasts and pound them out. They took 3 toothpicks each. I used an egg wash and coated in bread crumbs. I also used a sauce that was amazing. 2 tablespoons butter
2 tablespoons flour in a pan mix together over low heat, then add 1 cup milk 2 chicken bouillon cubes 1 tablespoon dry sherry 1 tablespoon Dijon mustard
1 teaspoon Worcestershire sauce makes a tangy creamy sauce that compliments it perfectly.

country:
None
text:
I made the breast/ham/cheese rolls and froze them a few weeks ago (didn't sprinkle with salt and pepper). I took them out of the freezer a couple of days ahead of time to thaw completely, sprinkled each roll with salt and pepper , then breaded them, dipping each in egg first, and topped each with a small pat of butter and baked. 
It was great! We had this not-so-quick and somewhatfancty entree on a Monday night after a busy workday in a flash! I totally recommend making several extra rolls (unbreaded) and freezing them for a quick and delicious entree on even the busiest nights!

text:
I've been making this for years with a few modifications.  Make your own bread crumbs by crushing garlic/butter croutons.  I add a slice of provolone in the middle and top with a half slice five minutes before it's done.  I've found that I get crispier coating by placing cooling racks in the baking dish and putting the chicken on top.  It does lessen the baking time.  This never misses with family!

text:
First off, I substituted the ham with some Johnsonville Mild Italian sausage. We enjoyed the added zing. It was a bit more difficult to wrap them up using the sausage vs. ham, tho. It took longer for the chicken to get 165 degrees so next time I think I would slice my chicken breasts thinner to help make the rolling up easier and the cooking faster. I pounded the heck out of mine and they they were still too thick. I forgot to make the sauce others recommend.  I think it would be even better with the mushroom sauce.

text:
This was incredibly easy to make and tasted great. I took others' advice and dipped each breast in an egg mix, then in bread crumbs (added dried parsley to the bread crumbs). Baked uncovered for 35 minutes at 350. However, the breasts were pretty big and I was worried they weren't fully cooked so I increased the temp to 385 and cooked for another 15 minutes. Perfect! Served with a tossed salad and - voil!  - a nice dinner made easy!

I loved it. I took the advice of the reviews and did an egg wash. I added cayenne pepper and Italian seasoning to the bread crumb mixture because I had non-seasoned crumbs. I like heat so I put a lot of cayenne pepper. And of course the salt and pepper so it had a lot of kick to it. Other than that, I used the recipe. Great recipe and it was on the easy side. My boyfriend loved it. I used the cream of chicken, sour cream and lemon juice as a sauce like someone recommended. Once again I added cayenne pepper to the sauce and onion salt. I served it with rice and steamed broccoli.

Very good and very easy! To keep it moist, I brushed the chicken with mayonaise before adding the breadcrumbs, and I made a honey mustard sauce for dipping. You could also drizzle the sauce on the chicken. I served this with a side and salad but it is very filling, so next time just a salad.

text:
This was awesome!  I beat the chicken down, then placed ham and cheese on top of the chicken breast and rolled it up.  I only had to put about 3 toothpicks in.  The key is to beat the chicken down pretty well, because it makes it super easy to roll!  Then I dredged the chicken in eggs, and rolled it in breadcrubs (Italian Flavored).  I browned the chicken rolls in olive oil for a few minutes, then put them in the oven with that yummy cream of mushroom sour cream and lemon juice!! Baked at 400 for 25 minutes, as suggested!!  OMG it was awesome!! No leftovers!! Everyone loved it....it was a BIG hit!!

This was so good, I'm not sure why previous reviewers felt they needed an egg wash.  I made it exactly as written and it was so moist and juicy!  I didn't see any reviews where it was tried both ways and the egg wash made a difference so I don't see it as necessary.  I used packaged ham and packaged swiss cheese... I saw some reviewers used provolone but I find that cheese very bland so not sure why they changed it.  It was delicious and so filling!  My man and I shared one breast and we are so full.  Thank you for sharing this recipe:)

text:
excellent new dish to add to the repetoire. Only deviated from the recipe by first dipping the chicken in egg and instead of bread crumbs I used spiced panko crumbs. To suit our spicy tastes, I added paprika, red pepper flake, montreal chicken seasoning, cayenne and garlic powder to the panko. Also put a little bit of Tapatio (Mexican hot sauce, tastes good with everything!) in the egg for a lil kick! No swiss on hand, so I used Monterey Jack. Was SPECTACULAR!!! Thanks so much for posting this recipe!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/305841.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I'm not a huge fan of chicken cordon bleu, but I know that my husband's family is so I made it for them.  The recipe is a great base, but I did what other posters suggested.  I also added bacon on the inside for more flavor.  I made the dressing to be one can of cream of chicken soup with 1/2 cup of sour cream and 1 tbsp of lemon juice.  I also added some Italian seasoning to the chicken before I rolled it up.  It was a great hit with the in-laws and the husband.  I kept a little extra dressing on the side, heated up, and they used it if desired (some did, some didn't).  I'll definitely make it again, but likely in a situation like that- making for the in laws.  Wasn't my personal favorite.

text:
Okay I have had 2 chicken cordon bleu recipes on this site and both are YUMMY!  The other you must saute which gives it a nice crisp texture. However, this recipe falls under Quick and Easy; only requires the oven and for the section it falls under Q&E I give it a 5! I butterflied the chicken to put the ham and swiss inside. Dipped in butter and rolled in seasoned bread crumbs.  Also poured 1/4 cup of white wine in the bottom of the pan to keep moist. As for the sauce I cheated and used a Knorr's Hollandaise Sauce and poured over at the end.

text:
My 9 yr old helped me make this today. He says "It was the best thing he ever tasted!" His favorite part was the breading. My husband loved it too. I followed some of the suggestions and used egg before using the Panko coating. I used 2 slices of ham and 2 slices of swiss each. It was a little difficult rolling it, but it managed to stay rolled w/the toothpicks. I also put a slice of butter on top of each piece. I made the cream of chicken/sour cream/lemon sauce. It was wonderful. We're definitely going to make this again. Thank you.

text:
I made this recipe, it was awseome I just changed the order. I got the brad crumbs ready. I mixed an egg in the bowl. Then I cut the chicken almost in half. I rolled two peices of ham with two peices of swiss cheeze and rolled. I then placed the roll inside the chicken. I dipped the chicken in the egg. Then I dipped in the breadcrumbs to completely cover both sides of the chicken.Then I put 1/4 butter on each breast. I placed the chicken in the pan and baked in the oven for 40 min. at 250 degrees. I made bowtie pasta with tomatoe sauce. Mixed the sauce with pasta and layed the chicken on top.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/60190.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very easy, simple to follow recipe. The only reason I did not rate it as a 5 star recipe was because I thought it lacked just a little bit of flavor. So what I did was add the white wine gravy from the "Chicken Cordon Bleu II" recipe on this site. However, since I avoided that whole recipe because of the high fat, I made a few adjustments which are as follows: I used 1 tbsp of butter, melted in a skillet, added 1 crushed chicken bouillon cube, 1/2 cup white cooking wine, 1/4 cup water, 1/4 cup heavy whipping cream, 1/4 cup milk, (or just 1/2 cup whipping cream if you dont want both). Let simmer and whisked off and on for about 10 minutes. Let stand in warm skillet until thickened. Salt and pepper to taste. VERY GOOD on this already good Chicken Cordon Bleu recipe. Have already made twice in the past 2 weeks just like this. Goes great w/ mashed potatoes. =D

Delicious! I made it mostly as the recipe calls for. Since I'm lazy, I cut the chicken breasts in half rather than pound them out. Also, don't forget the Swiss cheese on top at the end since it gives the top a good flavor.

text:
Had unexpected company for dinner the night I made these, and they were a hit! Dipped the rolled chicken breast in honey mustard, placed in pan, and then added the bread crumbs.  Baked at 400 for 20 minutes, then added extra cheese and cooked for another 5 minutes.  The honey mustard made a nice little bit of sauce in the pan, which I poured over the chicken after plating it.  Wonderful recipe!

country:
None
text:
I used processed pepper jack cheese, garlic flavored breadcrumbs, and leftover honey baked ham from Easter (this was because of several reviews stating that the recipe was good, but a little bland).  I also made the honey mustard sauce from the "Aussie Chicken" recipe on this site (as recommended by other reviewers, but I left out the corn syrup and used sour cream instead of mayo).  I will try "real" pepperjack cheese next time--I only had the processed kind on hand.  My husband LOVED this recipe and told me that he is looking forward to the leftovers as am I!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The chicken breasts I find at the store are huge and although my cordon bleu tasted good it would have been much better with smaller breasts.  The dominant taste in mine was chicken with only a hint of cheese or ham.  My advice, buy smaller breasts or cut them in half after pounding.  Also, it needs a sauce so I recommend adding a nice white wine sauce or something that doesn't over power the filling.

region:

country:
None
text:
As other reviewers have said, this is very simple and somewhat plain tasting.  It's nice for a change of pace, and works with a stronger flavored side dish.  It's extremely easy to put together - I didn't even need to use toothpicks, I just set the chicken seam-side down in the dish.  It was cooked through in 35 minutes, and I didn't find it too dry at all, especially not with all that cheese.  And it turned out very attractive looking, not sloppy like some similar recipes I've tried.

text:
Pretty good - not superb or anything but definately a nice easy, different way to prepare chicken. I used Proschuto ham (don't add salt) and Provolone cheese. I doused the whole thing in butter before baking - helped keep chicken moist. Very filling! Hard to eat a whole chicken breast after this treatment. Made the sauce to accompany it as well - nice dish overall.
